awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Inferring Spatio-Temporal Variations in the Risk of Extreme Precipitation in the Western United States from Tree Ring Chronologies
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to understand extreme cold-season precipitation dynamics along the west coast of the United States through an analysis of the moisture anomalies recorded by tree-ring chronologies across the coast and interior of the western U.S. Winters with high total precipitation amounts in the coastal regions are marked by a small number of extreme storms that exhibit distinct spatial patterns of precipitation across the coast and further inland.  Building from this observation, this research will seek to develop a novel application of dendroclimatic evidence to explore the following questions: a) how is extreme precipitation variability expressed in a network of tree-ring chronologies; b) can this information provide insight on the space-time variability of storm tracks that cause these extreme events; and c) how can the joint variability of extreme precipitation and storm tracks be modeled to develop consistent, multi-centennial reconstructions of both.

The broader impacts include the potential to better understand extreme precipitation events which exert significant social costs through both loss of life and substantial damage to property.  Society manages this burden using risk mitigation strategies (e.g., infrastructure, insurance) designed for historic extreme precipitation variability that is estimated from relatively short instrumental records and may be changing under anthropogenic climate change. This project will help determine how the frequency, persistence, recurrence and geographic pattern of these impacts have varied in the past under natural climate variability. This will provide important insights into the causes of these shifts and the potential for predictability in the future.  This project also provides support for graduate and post-doctoral researchers.

Outreach efforts will focus on high-level discussions with the L.A. County Flood Control District, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, and related agencies that manage extreme event risk in the region. This direct engagement will enhance the application of the research products, as well as provide guidance for their design. Innovative visualizations of research output will be made available through the Columbia Water Center for public use.

por.por_cntn:
The climate of the US West Coast is very variable, with prolonged droughts punctuated by extreme precipitation and flood events. These extremes are driven primary by the frequency of one type of storm event, known as atmospheric rivers (ARs), and the location where these storms make landfall along the coastline. Although measurements and models are available to quantify the frequency of these storms over the second half of the 20th century, it is not well understood how these storms have varied prior to this period. This knowledge gap makes it difficult to interpret the significance of emerging trends or climate model projections in AR activity and associated changes in extreme precipitation.

To address this gap, this project developed reconstructions of AR occurrences and extreme precipitation along the entire US West Coast based on tree-ring based moisture proxies back to the year 1400 CE. We developed these reconstructions first for sub-regions of the West Coast (southern California; the Sacramento River basin in Northern California), and then expanded the analysis to include AR landfalls along the entire coastline from southern California to Washington state. The results of our work showed that the frequency of extreme precipitation and AR landfalls along the West Coast has varied considerably over the last 600 years at multi-decadal timescales. We also showed that the latitude of AR landfall has varied considerably over this same period. The reconstructions developed in this work were then used to inform a stochastic weather generator that could simulate daily weather (precipitation and temperature) at the river basin scale. This process allowed us to develop large ensembles of weather traces from 1400 CE to present that reflect plausible sequences of weather consistent with past climate signals embedded in the tree ring record. These weather traces are being used by water agencies in California to explore the vulnerability of their systems to climate variations not seen in the instrumental record. Ultimately, the outcomes of this project support a transformative shift towards integrating state-of-the-art tree-ring based climate information into decision-making in the water sector in the Western US. This contribution is critically important given the growing stress that droughts and floods have placed on the Western US over recent decades.
